0: There's a new fighting app called Rumblr that is set to debut Monday at 5 p.m. ET. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR According to the app's Twitter account, users will only be able to access Rumblr through its website and not via a mobile app. The owners claim it's 100-percent real, although the photos and descriptions of the app seem absurd. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR MORE: 30 days of Ronda Rousey | What's next for the UFC champs? | Danica vs. Ronda NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Rumblr is an app for recreational fighters to find, meet, and fight other brawl enthusiasts nearby," its official website states. "You don’t need to fight to use Rumblr. With Rumblr Explore, anyone can browse and attend fights close by that other Rumblr users have arranged — all for free!" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The app claims to be "Tinder for fighting," referencing the popular dating app. Basically, users will find a match, schedule a fight and then go after one another. In one of the photos promoting the app, a user messages another user saying, "Bro your face is pissing me off. Wanna throw down?" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR #BrewOnThis: Let's Rumblr: Controversial New App Calls Itself The "Tinder For Fighting." Just Fine Or Over The Line? pic.twitter.com/eFH3RjrX67 — Fox & Friends First (@FoxFriendsFirst) November 9, 2015 NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR There's been some backlash to the app for obvious reasons. Setting up amateur fights amongst strangers probably isn't the best idea and could lead to some serious trouble. The owners of the app sort of addressed that issue in an interview with FightState.com. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "What happens when somebody gets killed?" the creator was asked. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We’re hands-off after the initial matchup. Hopefully, a funeral," they responded. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Whether they want to admit it or not, the developers of the app are essentially promoting unsanctioned fights, which a very dangerous proposition. All sanctioned fights must be cleared by state athletic boards, and to circumvent that process by enticing users to engage in unsanctioned fights is potentially dangerous for the sport. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Rumblr team also spoke with the New York Daily News and said they aren't in the App Store yet because they have to "hash out legal issues" before Rumblr is approved. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR They also told the Daily News that 78,000 people have already signed up for beta access to the app. app. NEWLINE_CHAR after unsanctioned addressed approved.
